variant.question:
Refer to figure.

The number in the annex that shows the retraction actuator is:

options.text: number 1.
number 4.
number 3.
number 2.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

The number in the annex that shows the steering actuator is:

options.text: number 2.
number 4.
number 1.
number 3.

variant.question: The type of brake unit found on most transport aeroplanes is a:

options.text: drum type brake.
multiple disk brake.
belt brake.
single disk brake.

variant.question: The nose-wheel steering system of a jet transport aeroplane can be controlled through the rudder pedals or a hand-wheel steering (tiller). Which statement is correct?

options.text: Rudder pedal nose-wheel steering offers the same maximum deflection of the nose wheel as hand-wheel steering (tiller).
Rudder pedal nose-wheel steering does not function during taxiing.
When performing a rudder check during taxiing, an additional pilot action must be taken to avoid deflection of the nose wheel.
Rudder pedal nose-wheel steering functions on the ground as well as in the air.

variant.question: Consider an aircraft with hydraulically operated brakes and a pneumatically operated emergency braking system, which uses the normal hydraulic brake lines. The aircraft also has an anti-skid system to avoid loss of control and locked wheels during braking. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: After using the emergency braking system, the brake pedals will feel softer underfoot.
Normal braking is available after using the emergency braking system, provided it is operational.
The anti-skid system will allow for a lower brake temperature when braking hard.
The emergency braking system will be able to stop in a shorter distance, compared to normal braking.

variant.question:
In large aeroplanes, how is nose-wheel steering accomplished?

1\. Aileron control wheel.   
 2\. Rudder pedals.   
 3\. Differential braking.   
 4\. Separate steering wheel.

options.text: 1 and 3.
1 and 2.
3 and 4.
2 and 4.

variant.question: Which of these statements about rudder pedal nose wheel steering is correct?

options.text: Rudder pedal nose wheel steering functions on the ground as well as in the air.
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering does not function during take-off.
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering provides a larger deflection of the nose wheel as manual or tiller control.
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering provides a smaller deflection of the nose wheel as hand wheel steering (tiller).

variant.question: Select the option that best describes "nose-wheel shimmy"

options.text: An oscillatory longitudinal movement of the nose-wheel about the lateral axis of the aircraft when the nose wheel is in contact with the runway during the take-off or landing run.
An oscillatory longitudinal movement of the nose-wheel about the lateral axis of the aircraft caused by the landing gear being lowered prior to landing or retracted after take-off.
An oscillatory lateral movement of the nose-wheel about the longitudinal axis of the aircraft caused by the landing gear being lowered prior to landing or retracted after take-off.
An oscillatory lateral movement of the nose-wheel about the longitudinal axis of the aircraft when the nose wheel is in contact with the runway during the take-off or landing run.

variant.question: Which statement is correct regarding nose wheel steering using the tiller or rudder pedals?

options.text: When checking the rudder during taxi, the pilot has to consider nose-wheel turn.
Pedals and nosewheel are usually disconnected during taxi.
The steering angle is the same when using the rudder pedals or nose-wheel steering tiller.
Nose-wheel steering also works when using the rudder pedals in flight.

variant.question: Which of these statements about rudder pedal nose wheel steering is correct?

options.text: Rudder pedal nose wheel steering functions on the ground only.
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering provides the same deflection of the nose wheel as hand wheel steering (tiller) control.
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering provides a larger deflection of the nose wheel as hand wheel steering (tiller).
Rudder pedal nose wheel steering does not function during take-off.
